item.title: Best XI of the Nepal Premier League 2024/25
item.description:
The inaugural season of the Siddhartha Bank Nepal Premier League 2024/25 showcased stellar performances across teams. After much deliberation, here’s our Best Overall XI, featuring players who excelled with their consistent displays throughout the tournament.

Key criteria for selection:

  • A fieldable team with a good ratio of batsmen, bowlers, , all-rounders, and a wicketkeeper.
  • No restrictions on the number of overseas players (check out the Best Fieldable XI for the best XI team with 4 overseas players).

Overall Best XI

1. Lahiru Milantha (Opener/Wicketkeeper, Janakpur Bolts, overseas)

  • Batting: 293 runs in 10 innings, Avg 32.55, SR 130.80, HS 87

Milantha ended the tournament as the top run scorer but his path through the tournament had peaks and troughs. He started the tournament with a bang, scoring an unbeaten 75 against the Kings. His performances trended downwards after that but he came back strong in the final with a match-winning 87 off 49 balls. As such, he narrowly edges out Andries Gous for the opener’s spot in this Best XI with the weight of his performances in the final for a winning cause for the Bolts.

item.title: Underwhelming XI of the Nepal Premier League 2024/25
item.description:
The first edition of the Siddhartha Bank Nepal Premier League 2024/25 saw several players underperform relative to expectations.Below is a list of my subjective Underwhelming XI, featuring players who couldn’t deliver their best this season.

Key criteria for selection of this 11 include:

  • A team with 4 overseas picks, at least 1 uncapped player, at least 1 marquee player, and a fieldable mix of bowlers, wicketkeeper, and batsmen.
  • Underwhelming does not mean a list of worst performers, but rather players who failed to meet expectations or deliver on their potential.

Underwhelming XI

1. Aashutosh Ghiraiya (Opener, Lumbini Lions, uncapped)

  • Batting: 44 runs in 6 innings, Avg 7.33, SR 62.85, HS 16

Aashutosh Ghiraiya had a tough campaign for the Lumbini Lions in the NPL 2024/25. Known for his stellar domestic performances, especially in the Prime Minister’s Cup earlier this year, Ghiraiya struggled to find any kind of form in this tournament. His inability to provide solid starts as an opener left the Lions in a precarious position early in their innings. This disappointing performance was a far cry from the expectations set by the teams during the player draft as he was sold for the highest price for Category B players.
